body: Will do tomorrow. See also https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/8296 so this may not be a windows specific thing. #8296 just had 2/3 failures, but I recall seeing that third failure another time.
@TomAugspurger thanks, yes these fail on linux too (on travis we are not testing this ATM)

I would check the boxplot failures with mpl-master.  We have a couple of (now fixed) bugs in boxplot.  

cc @phobson

OK there were two changes that affected our tests (I'm running mpl and pandas off the latest mater).
1. Handling of empty arrays. In `test_graphics:TestDataFramePlots.test_boxplot_empty_column`
   One of the columns in the DataFrame is all NaNs. ~~I'll try to come up with a self contained example, but for now~~ (EDIT: Added a cleaner example in comment below):

Here's the matplotlib portion of the stack trace:

``` python
  /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/matplotlib-1.5.x-py3.4-macosx-10.9-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/axes/_axes.py(3045)boxplot()
   3043         """
   3044         bxpstats = cbook.boxplot_stats(x, whis=whis, bootstrap=bootstrap,
-> 3045                                        labels=labels)
   3046         if flierprops is None:
   3047             flierprops = dict(sym=sym)

  /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/matplotlib-1.5.x-py3.4-macosx-10.9-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/cbook.py(1966)boxplot_stats()
   1964 
   1965         # medians and quartiles
-> 1966         q1, med, q3 = np.percentile(x, [25, 50, 75])
   1967 
   1968         # interquartile range

  /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py(2820)percentile()
   2818         axis = 0
   2819 
-> 2820     return _compute_qth_percentile(sorted, q, axis, out)
   2821 
   2822 # handle sequence of q's without calling sort multiple times

  /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py(2826)_compute_qth_percentile()
   2824     if not isscalar(q):
   2825         p = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted, qi, axis, None)
-> 2826              for qi in q]
   2827 
   2828         if out is not None:

> /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py(2826)<listcomp>()
   2824     if not isscalar(q):
   2825         p = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted, qi, axis, None)
-> 2826              for qi in q]
   2827 
   2828         if out is not None:

  /Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py(2856)_compute_qth_percentile()
   2854     # Use add.reduce in both cases to coerce data type as well as
   2855     #   check and use out array.
-> 2856     return add.reduce(sorted[indexer]*weights, axis=axis, out=out)/sumval

ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (0,) (2,) 
```

Here are the values:

``` python
ipdb> sorted[indexer]
array([], dtype=float64)
ipdb> weights
array([ 1.25, -0.25])
ipdb> indexer
[slice(0, 2, None)]
ipdb> sorted[indexer] * weights
*** ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (0,) (2,)
```

At first glance this looks like a matplotib regression I think.

---

The scond change: a change in the number of lines per box in the boxplot. Before it was 8, now it's 7.

``` python
In [14]: fig, ax = plt.subplots()

In [15]: ax.boxplot(np.random.randn(30))
Out[15]: 
{'means': [],
 'caps': [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x111239e80>,
  <matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x11123e908>],
 'boxes': [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x111239a20>],
 'fliers': [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x111816908>],
 'whiskers': [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x111232208>,
  <matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x11122f6d8>],
 'medians': [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x111816128>]}
```

This one looks to be intentional, is that correct @phobson, @tacaswell ? Our tests were expecting 8 lines per box. We can just change that to 7.

Smaller example for the first one:

``` python

In [14]: fig, ax = plt.subplots()

In [15]: ax.boxplot([np.array([]), np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-15-febecc8c1634> in <module>()
----> 1 ax.boxplot([np.array([]), np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])])

   3044         bxpstats = cbook.boxplot_stats(x, whis=whis, bootstrap=bootstrap,
-> 3045                                        labels=labels)
   3046         if flierprops is None:
   3047             flierprops = dict(sym=sym)

/Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/matplotlib-1.5.x-py3.4-macosx-10.9-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/cbook.py in boxplot_stats(X, whis, bootstrap, labels)

-> 1966         q1, med, q3 = np.percentile(x, [25, 50, 75])
   1967

   2819 
-> 2820     return _compute_qth_percentile(sorted, q, axis, out)
   2821 
   2822 # handle sequence of q's without calling sort multiple times

/Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py in _compute_qth_percentile(sorted, q, axis, out)
   2824     if not isscalar(q):
   2825         p = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted, qi, axis, None)
-> 2826              for qi in q]
   2827 
   2828         if out is not None:

/Users/tom/Envs/py3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/numpy/lib/function_base.py in <listcomp>(.0)

   2825         p = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted, qi, axis, None)
-> 2826              for qi in q]

-> 2856     return add.reduce(sorted[indexer]*weights, axis=axis, out=out)/sumval
   2857

ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (0,) (2,)
```

We have an outstanding issue regarding the fliers so I am not sure which way that one is going to go.

I agree the `ValueError` one looks like a regression.

Here's the [fliers issue](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/3544).

@jreback OK with skipping these for now? I'll skip if we detect mpl 1.4 or dev (which is labeled `'1.5.x'). When those are closed I'll come back and remove the skips for 1.5 & possibly change some of the tests depending on how the fliers issue goes.
sure that's fine, just create a reminder issue for next version!

@TomAugspurger remember #8240 just got merged a week ago, as an attempt to fix the empty boxplot issue. I tried to work around empty columns by putting a single `np.nan` into the empty array. It's that behaviour which is now failing in the tests, i.e.

``` python
ax.boxplot([np.array([np.nan]), np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])]) 
```

If matplotlib fixes the empty columns issue, we might want to go back to leaving the empty column empty?
Fixing the boxplot issues is on the blocker list for 1.4.1.
